questions.question: Sam as well as his friends ...................... studying.
questions.description: When two nouns are connected by as well as, the verb agrees with the former subject.

questions.question: ........................ I was annoyed, I kept quiet.
questions.description: Either although or even though is possible here. Even though is more emphatic than although.

questions.question: When I was a child I ....................... to be an astronaut.
questions.description: The simple past is the most normal tense for talking about past states or actions.

questions.question: The cow as well as the goat ....................... us milk.
questions.description: When we connect two singular nouns with as well as, the verb is singular.

questions.question: The beggar lay on the ground ......................... he were dead.
questions.description: Either as if or as though is possible here. As if and as though are used to talk about how a situation seems.

questions.question: ....................... she was a generous woman, everyone liked her.
questions.description: As gives the reason though is similar to but.

questions.question: He is ....................... to buy a mansion.
He was ......................... weak to even sit up.
questions.description: Note the pattern too...to. It is also possible to write 'He was so weak that he could not even sit up.'

questions.question: The place was ......................... quiet that he decided to stay there.
questions.description: So...that gives the cause and effect.

questions.question: It was ......................... a hot day that I felt lethargic.
questions.description: Such is used before adjective + noun.

questions.question: If I won the lottery, I ........................ a home.
questions.description: In the second conditional, use a simple past in the if-clause and would + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ....................... the glass, it will break.
questions.description: In the first conditional, use a simple present in the if-clause and will + first form of the verb in the main clause.
